We're hearing about changes in grain in particular that are coming through. So, it's likely the prices there will increase. But if you look beyond the more recent spike in the last 12 months, the price of grain has fallen by about 15% during that period. And probably people operating smartly in that market would have been hedging forward on the price. So, it will emerge over time and like anything else, if there are legitimate price increases that are required then we'll listen to them sympathetically, but we've got to make sure that they're justifiable, because just simply passing on to the consumers is not something we would advocate.
But I suppose that begs the question, will you look to, in effect, fund suppliers for those legitimate price increases, but wear the cost yourself?

Again, that will come into our overall investment decision as we go through the year. The reduction in milk, for example, which is often quoted, we funded that reduction ourselves. So, we will look at where our underlying pricing strategy is and where we're getting savings out of our business. And there are other cost pressures as well, which are coming through and we're seeking to mitigate them. And we know that working with our suppliers, we can seek to see them, mitigate them too. So, hopefully, it won't just be a straight pass through, but we'll be watching very carefully over the coming months.
And that mitigation of cost pressures, are you including utility costs there?

Well, we'll look at all aspects of what we're doing and certainly as you've seen within the capital, the CapEx during the course of this year, in part the increase has been through acceleration of our refrigeration changes, and that means that our refrigeration is becoming more efficient. We've also taken some further steps to improve our energy efficiency as well. So, I think over the last four years, although volume's gone up by 20%, our energy costs have come down by 11%. And therefore, we're looking to exploit further opportunities to become more energy efficient too.
Okay. Thanks, all.
And your next question comes from the line of Andrew McLennan from CBA. Please ask your question.

I've got a question for John first, just in relation to the impact of the housing cycle, I just wanted to try and get my head around how much of an impact on the lower comp sales that we're seeing at the moment is due to the tighter trading conditions as opposed to the deflationary component? You don't mention any difficulty in terms of impacting the outlook.

Thanks, Andrew. If you can recall back to the investor presentation, I spoke about the market having the distinctions of consumer; light commercial and heavy commercial. The housing cycle has the most impact on the heavy commercial side of the market and we're not immune from those impacts. We're able to offset them by doing other work in light commercial and other work in consumer. So, there is not much of a drag inside the store comp number, but obviously there is a little.

And if you can reflect back on that, I think at the time I talked about the fact that there's – the heavy – there's about 20% of our total turnover that is commercial. And between heavy and light, it's very subjective as to how you measure it, but it's possibly around the 50/50 mark. And the heavy participates in our stores and through our trade centers in a blend as well. So, hopefully, that will give you some guidance.
Yeah, it does. So, that would suggest that a lot of the discount to – or reduction in your comparable sales growth is, in fact, due to the deflationary impact of your initiatives basically?

Well, that's right. And we've been very frank in forecasting that and calling it out and saying it's going to happen. So, that's been a consistent theme, where we set out to achieve stronger value points for customers and to deliver that, it's been an underlying theme in our business, the productivity loop. It's been part of what the Bunnings' long-run success has been about, finding ways to create more value for our customer and going after more volume from that and investing more of what you can get back into doing something else that gives you the ability to do that again on another product or in another way.

We work on the cost of product. We work on our cost of doing business. So, we're in a position to reinvest productivity gains and we've really accelerated that across the last 24 months or so. Particularly, this year has borne most of the impact.

Okay. And in terms of liquor, there was a mentioned that there was significant disruptions in the first half of 2012. Can we anticipate a significant improvement in sales trends as you circle those disruptions? How bad was it?

Well, I think it was a pretty significant disruption. It was a major mainframe system change and it didn't go well, frankly. And we've actually resolved the issues now, but in order to resolve them, it took a fair amount of time, effort and focus from management to ensure that that happened. And it was a disruption during the course of the first half.

And so, certainly, now we've got a much stronger position. And it isn't necessarily about your sales. I think that the issue with sales is that we want to see, clearly, improvements. But we want to make sure those sales are profitable. And one of the things that we intend to stop doing is wholesaling, particularly, on beer through our large-scale format. And therefore, that will still have a bearing on our underlying sales performance. By our underlying volumes we'd expect to start to improve, where we got the profitable sales coming through, particularly in the smaller box, which actually is a larger part of our total liquor business anyway.
Okay. Thank you.
Your next question comes from the line of Craig Woolford of Citi, Sydney. Please ask your question.

Good afternoon, guys. My first question is on the Coles business and in particular understanding the step-up in margin expansion for the second half. From my numbers, Coles, excluding fuel, EBIT margins are up 51 basis points, second half, year-on-year, and only 29 basis points in the first half. Of that improvement in the second half, how much would you attribute to the flood impacts that, obviously, had hurt the second half 2011 results? I think, it was quite a meaningful impact, but was never called out separately. I just want to understand that one-off factor.

Yeah. I wouldn't read too much into it. The time that we had the floods, there was actually pluses and minuses on that. I mean, what you had – because it was pretty well voiced in the media that floods were going to take place, what we actually saw was a lot of people pantry filling. So, we had actually a surge in sales, which was then offset by negatives, as the floods set and certain stores were taken down for a few days. But we never call it out as a material impact at the time.
So, that was just --

You can read into the fact that we had the floods last year and therefore we've got some gains this year, and read that through. The margin expansion that we're seeing is a result of the efforts to manage the business effectively, drive more efficiency through the business and improve our volumes and fractionalize our costs in the stores.
Okay. Maybe this question for Terry. Just to clarify, remember from last year, it was called out a $40 million flood impact or thereabout, is that --?
Yes, broadly. We took – we --
In the segment.
We took an Insurance provision effectively for that, that we were, very – well, you have to be 100% confident you're going to get and then we called out the balance. It was about that amount, Craig.
So, that $40 million was within each of the segments that were impacted?
Yeah. I'd say, across the group, it was about that. And we said at the time that it was majority Coles.

Yeah. My second question is about the Kmart business. Obviously, a fantastic result and an impressive EBIT margin expansion. Is EBIT margin a KPI or a focus point for that business, because I guess it's almost at odds with the philosophy of the business about offering lower prices? But you'd mainly want to see revenue growth than a lapse in good customer transaction growth. But I'm just interested in what position you take on, on a 6.6% EBIT margin or whether you're happy to see that rise further?

Yeah. Thanks, Craig. EBIT margin is a KPI for all of us. But, our focus, as I outlined to all of you and I have for the last few years, we are very, very focused about two things: providing everyday items for consumers, which is what's reduced the SKU count from 120,000 down to 50,000, and the second part of that is to provide the lowest-possible prices we can. Our prices have dropped significantly over the last three years. They have dropped, again, significantly in the last 12 months. And even as of recently, with the campaign, I highlighted in my briefing notes, about lower than ever, I think, we dropped another few hundred prices to our consumers over the months of April, May and June.

So, the path that allows us to do this, which gives us a win-win for the EBIT for shareholders and for customers is by being very focused on being a low-cost business. So, we drive costs out of the business, not only through direct sourcing, which we've had significant change in the last two years, but we drive costs right out of the business in every line on the P&L. So --
Do you think you're the lowest-cost DDS operator?
Say that again?
Do you think you're the lowest-cost DDS operator in Australia?
Am I...?
Is Kmart the lowest-cost operator as a discount department store?
Well, yeah. I do.
Okay. Thanks. Thank you.
Craig, as Guy said, it's a KPI, but it's an outcome that we measure across all businesses, obviously. But they're outcomes, not how we try and manage the business.
Sure. Thank you.
Your next question comes from the line of David Thomas of CLSA. Please ask your question.

Hi, guys. First question is actually for Dene Rogers on Target. Obviously, a very strong turnaround in the second half. I know at the sales briefing they talked about bringing forward a toy sales event, which helped the top line. I was wondering if you could sort of give some quantification about that on the bottom line.

Yeah. Hey, David. I can't give you a quantification on the bottom line. What I can say in qualitative terms was that an amount of sales brought forward about 10 days that were in fiscal 2011 were brought forward into fiscal 2012 on a year-by-year basis. And the profitability of those sales were enhanced by not only a focus on toy sales themselves, but also at looking to sell other products while the customer traffic was up and so the profitability of the toy sales increased because of that strategy and some changes in the marketing.

Okay. All right. Thanks, Dene. And secondly for Ian. We've done a fair bit of surveying and describe what the press say, actually, customers seem to like our private label and in particular Coles. And I'm interested by your commentary about the thousand new SKUs and wondering if they're sort of replacement SKUs or if they're incremental SKUs and how is your private label growth going relative to the core business?

Well, obviously, your survey is clearly wrong and it just can't be taken as a given, really. How can customers possibly enjoy private label when it's as good a value as in terms of quality and much better pricing, but I'll take it at your word. We are very encouraged by the way the private label is going. We've put a lot of effort into how we're developing it. We're still getting strong sales out of it. It's growing faster than the brand. And I think that's because we've not just looked at the new products coming in, but we looked at enhancing the quality. And that's been very important in terms of getting customer credibility.

Certainly, what we've seen as the consumer confidence levels have been pretty low from where they have been and people are saving more, then they're looking for ways in which they can save money in their grocery bill as well. And private label has offered them a real opportunity. And we are looking at it to making sure that still is maintained as an integral part of our strategy. We've invested in equipment. We've invested in people and we're working closely with some very small suppliers at times to kind of bring more products to the market.

The initiative we've put in place this year on making sure that every one of our Coles brand products has no artificial flavors, no artificial colors, is an industry first as well. It just demonstrates our commitment to quality in this area. So, I can see that continuing to expand. We don't put targets on it. Ultimately, the customer will decide what they want to buy and what they don't. But we're very pleased with the continued progress in that area.

And just as a quick follow-up. Obviously, your competitors talk fairly definitively about sort of targets they were trying to get to and I don't expect you to, perhaps, fall into that same trap. But I was wondering if you could talk about some of the categories where you see the biggest opportunities going forward?

I mean, there's no one category. We're looking at it across the board. I think that fresh food presents particular opportunities for us and we've seen opportunities in key trading times like Easter and Christmas, where we brought in additional ranges of product in meat, for example, with our finest range and also in bakery as well. And I know that this Christmas again we'll have a stronger selection of products in that particular area. And it's engendering higher levels of customer trust. Once they bought them one year, they're coming back and buying them again and it's actually given them opportunity to further invest across the board. So, I wouldn't call out any particular area, but we see fresh goods as an opportunity.
Okay. Thanks, guys.
Your next question comes from the line of Grant Saligari of Credit Suisse, Melbourne. Please ask your question.
Thank you. Good afternoon. First question on the capital expenditure outlook. I'd appreciate it if you could just elaborate on some of the divisional ups and downs in that outlook?

I guess, what we say is that we expect Resources to probably not be as high, because of the expenditure completions or the wrap-up of the expansion works there. It's likely that WES CEF (95:38) will be higher than this year, because of ammonium nitrate expansion really progressing through. Elsewhere, look, it would probably be reasonably similar and it will be property that's fluctuating numbers. And I guess, where we – so, where we're seeing a reduction at the moment, to John's point, is that in terms of net CapEx, is we did $275 million worth of sales this year. And if we get out in the first quarter with a lot of that already tucked away, we've got nine months of probably further property activity that will bring down the net. So, that's probably as much guidance I'll give you at this stage. At the half, obviously, we'll give you a bit further guidance on where things are going.
Just to clarify on the CEF, how of the $550 million expansion have you spent already?
We've spent $100 million mostly in the last year, but a little bit in 2011 and we're likely to spend more like $300 million in this current financial year.

Okay. Second question, just on the Insurance division, if I could. Maybe just to clarify the gross premium growth on the second half seemed quite low. The net premium growth was actually quite high. So, I just wonder if you could clarify what was happening there. And maybe just a bit of a view as to what the Insurance margin would be in the business now on a normal claims experience?

Sure. Grant, I can explain that relationship between GEP and NEP. So, there are few factors that drive that. The first was, as we mentioned, we did let a fair bit of premium go this year in high-risk areas. So, that had a negative impact on GWP. But then we gained some GWP through rate increases. The other factor that was also quite material, which doesn't impact revenue, reported revenue or EBIT in any way, was that in the previous year we were required – in 2011, at yearend, we were required to account for some long-term premium around leased motor fleet, which resulted in the year-on-year comparison between 2011 and 2012 being a bit distorted. Because it didn't impact revenue or EBIT, we don't bother going to the disclosure. But if you adjusted for that, that would have an impact of – that would increase our GWP on a like-for-like basis to close to 10% growth for the year.
Okay. And in terms of just the normal margin outlook just given what's been happening with your reinsurance costs and your premium rates?

Yeah. So, we put in there, I guess, an underlying core of around 90%, 96%. We'd expect to see that in a normal year or a bit better. On the broking side, we would expect to see a bit of pressure on broking margin in our business, because we're undergoing quite a major investment in systems. But we would still expect to see growth in earnings in that business.
Okay. Thank you for that.
Your next question comes from the line of Greg Dring of Macquarie. Please ask your question.

Thanks. A question for Tom. Tom, you're a major beneficiary of price movements, you called out across Chem, Energy & Ferts. Historically, we've had discussions about how much of your tonnes are actually exposed to spot movements and of course formally worked this over in May, the year before last. But you seem to have a lot of exposure to price, and can you give us a feel for what that percentage is in the business and how it might change going forward?

I can't give you a direct percentage exposure. But what I can say is that in our ammonia business, we're in the process of moving our key external customers over to international ammonia-based pricing rather than fixed pricing. So, going forward, we're going to be much more exposed to international ammonia prices. In sodium cyanide, for example, those contracts are much shorter term. They're sort of two, three-year contracts sometimes. In ammonium nitrate, they tend to be much longer-term contracts.
And maybe I can ask the question another way. Your average pricing in Chems up $3 (100:08) and Fertilisers up $6 (100:10), where did that come from? Which commodities or chemical?
Well, as I've said, we did get stronger pricing at ammonia, ammonium nitrate and sodium cyanide. And in Fertilisers, it's probably across the board, I'd say, and Fertilisers wouldn't be specific.
But you haven't moved any of these future contracts? You're getting the benefit of price. So, there is a certain percentage of your business that's still exposed to spot movement?
Yeah, there is. There is and an increasing percentage in our ammonia business, which is the 250,000 tonne per annum plant.
But that's not merchant ammonia sales, is it?

No, it's not merchant ammonia sales. They tend to be longer-term contracts. But the pricing, as I said, is moving from long-term fixed pricing with steady increases with CPI or some other movement indicator towards international ammonia price, which is moving every month. So, that is becoming, in effect, a merchant pricing plant, but on long-term contract basis.
Okay. Thanks.
And your next question comes from the line of Tom Kierath of Morgan Stanley. Please ask your question.

Afternoon, guys. Just a question on Bunnings. There has been, obviously, a bit of a slowdown in the last six months. I just want to understand whether the new stores you've rolled out has diluted the profit growth in these last six months and then how you're kind of thinking, I guess, based on that ahead?

Hi, Tom. Thanks for the question. There's actually no slowdown at all. If you look at the EBIT splits, first half and second half, I think this year it's sort of a 57%-42% (102:02). In financial year 2008, it's 56%-44% (102:07). Yeah. First half is always bigger than the second half and this year was no different to any other. I think people are trying to read something in that's not there, frankly.
But could you talk about then the impact of the new stores and whether that – like are store is profitable in the first year or is that dilution impact from that?

We aim for our new stores to be profitable immediately and we have a very strong record in delivering on that. I can't say it's 100%, but it's very close to 100%. The ramp-up of new stores can be quite different state to state, and that's based around just some localized characteristics. We find the Sydney Basin stores take a few more years to ramp to the sort of levels that we are chasing versus maybe a Perth or a Melbourne store. And if we're entering a fresh market, like the South Island of New Zealand, then obviously you've got to do a lot of brand building to ramp the numbers.

In terms of impact of new stores, the other factor is whether we're landing a whole clutch of stores in very new turf or whether we're opening a store that's replacing an older store. And when we do that, there's generally a very significant lift in the space. So just the other week, the second ever Bunnings Warehouse at Mentone, which is just to touch over 11,000 square meters was replaced by a new Mentone on the Nylex plastics site, fantastic site, a couple of hundred meters down the road that gave us close to 8,500, 9,000 square meters. So, it's called one store, but it's not one store and it's a significant impact to shift the store of that like. And you're growing from an existing base.

Another factor is just the level of cannibalization that may or may not be occurring. And these are all quite lumpy over time. So, in any one quarter or half, it's typical to be calling out one or the other. If you look at it over the long run, we're quite pleased with how our new stores start up, how they get out of the ground and have achieved their longer-term goals in terms of returns and customer characteristics and the sort of share we're able to get in the immediate draw areas.
Okay. Thanks, John.
Your next question comes from the line of Daniel Broeren of RBS. Please ask your question.

Good afternoon. I've got a question for Stewart, please. As you mentioned earlier, Stewart, the spot hard coking price has dropped below $170. Can you just talk about how your negotiated pricing relates to movements in spot? So, the 20% drop in spot, usually, result in a 20% drop in the next contracted price?

Well, it certainly indicates downward pressure on quarterly pricing. And quarterly pricing, at the moment, sits at around about $220 to $225 for the Q3. Spot price has been in that US$180 to US$190 per tonne. And we're starting to see some falloff in steel demand, some capacities coming off from the steelmakers. So, they're all indicating that prices are heading downwards. And as I said before in the presentation, the spot price is down by about 20% compared to term.

Ultimately, the next quarter prices will be determined by supply and demand and what's happening in the marketplace. So, we'll have to – I don't – at this stage, I won't give a call on what the pricing will be for Q4. But clearly, there pressure heading downwards in terms of pricing for that quarter.

I guess, just to clarify, is there a degree of resilience in your negotiated pricing that would mean that a drop in a negotiated pricing would be less than what the spot has dropped by or do they normally follow it in the same relation?

Look, the spot price tends to be a leading indicator. And quarterly, the prices tend to follow it down. Whether they go down to the same level as spot price, that's still yet to be determined and that will all unfold over the next six weeks when we roll into negotiations for the Q4 pricing.

Right. Okay. Thanks. And John, I think you said earlier that the disruption from price reset peaked in fiscal 2012. So, do you think sales growth and margin can expand in fiscal 2013 as a result of that? Or do you think market conditions will get the lead on any upside at this stage?

Well, it's an interesting crystal ball question. On margin, it will be what it will be. We're quite comfortable with current levels and they're an outcome, as Richard pointed out, so I won't comment on that. The outlook that we've said is that we expect to trade well. The range reset, from a negotiation point of view, was very disruptive and very intensive for our merchandising team across most of calendar 2011. And then, more recently, the intensity has been for operational teams and it's been very disruptive that led to one of the reasons why we had a little bit more of the high injury levels, which is very disappointing. But there's just so much to do in the store to reset the ranges that we were doing.

So, I think ops teams are really looking forward to having a crack at spring and summer, free of having to deal with reset as well, and if we get the right weather conditions, last year spring was good and summer was bad. So far, we're sitting waiting for winter to end and we're looking forward with quite wet conditions down the East Coast to a good growing season for spring and, hopefully, a good summer. On the West Coast, they're talking drought, unfortunately. So, it's amazing the differences we've got, but it's hard to forecast things. Conditions around weather for spring and summer are really critical for our business.
Okay. Thank you for that.
Your next question comes from the line of Michael Simotas with Deutsche Bank. Please ask you question.

Hi, guys. Maybe just a quick one for Terry. Terry, I was hoping you could give us a little bit of guidance on the outlook for depreciation in the business. Does the level of growth in depreciation seem to slow a little bit in the second half? And I know we've spoken in the past about how it can be lumpy when different properties, in particular, come online. What do you think the outlook is for FY 2013?

Look, I guide – I mean, it's not something I particularly want to give guidance on – I think what you're clearly going to see is Resources, as you've seen, jump as the new plant is, obviously, on line and being depreciated. Yeah. You've seen a reasonable jump in Coles and that's the refurbishment activity obviously, renewal activity biting into that business. I think the trends that you're seeing are not un-surprising, I would have thought. We've said that a lot of the growth CapEx is – we've really called out where that's going, and we've said the rest is maintenance CapEx and we've said that maintenance CapEx, for us, largely means replacing things at the same rate of depreciation. So, that would broadly keep you in line. So, I think that's probably as good a guidance as we'd give.
Okay. So, it sounds like you're saying the trend into next year will be broadly similar compared to this year other than Resources?

Yeah. I mean, you've got to just take note of where the major CapEx has been spent, in terms of refurbishment programs and expansion programs in particular, because that's the areas that are driving ahead of depreciation, and I guess where it's land and buildings, clearly not a lot of depreciation in those areas. So, that's not going to be a big driver. And where it's work-in-progress, such as in Chemicals, Energy & Ferts, that's not depreciating at this stage, so that's not a driver. So, I think if you think through the guidance we're giving you around where the CapEx is going and the divisions is going, you'll get it reasonably close.

Yeah. Although, if we look at the level of CapEx in the Coles food and liquor, for example, a lot of that's been on refurb over the past couple of years, and there actually hasn't been a very large increase in depreciation or not what the increase in CapEx would suggest?
In, sorry, liquor?
In Coles food and liquor. Coles, yeah.

Yeah. Well, we were getting comments at the half about why it was so hot, why it jumped up so high. So, I think if you go and look at the 4E, there has been reasonable increase in depreciation in Coles over the course of the year. And as I said, a lot of the CapEx in this year as we've called out was an increase in the amount of freehold property that we were taking onboard to develop the underlying levels of, if you like, property, plant and equipment was a similar number of refurbishments. So, I take property to be an increasing proportion of what was going through Coles CapEx and so on (111:17).
Okay. Thanks.
Your next question comes from the line of Phillip Kimber with Goldman Sachs, Melbourne. Please ask your question.

Hi. Just to follow-up on the Coles property. I know it's small in the scheme of things, but it can be material in a growth rates sense. And I seem to recall it was quite a low number last year. Can you provide us what the 2011 property --?
Yes. $5 million last year.
Okay. And if I go back to the year before, it was more in line with that $20 million a year, why was it so low last year?

Perhaps, Ian might give more flavor, but I think it's largely to do with Clive Peeters. So, we had a provision in relation to the leases, that they were in, effectively, because we owned the property.
And I assume that there is no revenue associated with that. So, that would also have helped those margins in the second half of the year.

If you think about it, it's a drop because you've got effectively – when you think of it, perhaps, an impairment is the best way to describe it, on those leases, you're not going to get rent from Clive Peeters where you once were. So, you take a hit.

There were two key elements on it from last year. I mean, obviously, with the Clive Peeters issue, that meant we had to take a provision against it, because we didn't think we'd be able to fill that space for the subtenant. We've actually been quite successful. So, that's enabled us to release some of those provisions back. And as I mentioned earlier on, we've actually been quite proactive in making sure that any vacancy we had within specialties around our own field of properties where we've got supermarkets, we worked quite hard to fill those vacancies and that's helped to grow the number as well.
Okay. And can I also ask on liquor, whether your EBIT for the liquor business grew in 2012 on 2011?

We don't go into detail in terms of what's happening to our overall margins at that level and we just only quote our food and liquor number. And I'll just repeat what I've said before is that we're pretty encouraged by the level of profitability that we're getting out of liquor in the second half, and it's giving us more encouragement for the performance of liquor during the course of the financial year that we're currently in.
Okay. Thanks.
Your next question comes from the line of Shaun Cousins of JPMorgan. Please ask your question.

Hey. Thanks. Just a question in regards to Chem, Energy & Ferts, can you talk about how much the growth came out of – was it all Chemicals or Fert or just in terms of – if could just give us an indication of where that growth came from, please?

Yeah. Well, look, Fertilisers had a good year, particularly on volumes, as you'll have seen, but the key driver of the increase was really our ammonia business. You might recall that we'd flagged that we'd thought that the ammonia business would be down because of the shutdown that was late in the first half. But we did a lot better in that shut than we had expected both in terms of cost, but importantly in time, it was much shorter than we'd budgeted, if you like.

Also, one of our key ammonia customers experienced some production difficulties that we were able to help them with through some short-term arrangements that we hadn't anticipated. And the international ammonia pricing, as I've said, helped as well. So, it's really in ammonia was the driver.
And just in terms of Insurance. You've made the point about 96% underlying combined operating ratio. When are we likely to see that given that hasn't been reported by the division since 2007?

Well, I guess, Shaun, as I said, the last couple of years have been very unusual years, a combination of softening rates in the lead up, major catastrophe events and then structural change in reinsurance markets, which we needed to adapt to. So, last year has been tough. What we believe we've done in our business now is, through strengthening the underlying performance we have far more resilience to handle some one-off events. And that's really what we're focused on. So, the number that we've put forward at around the 96% mark is what we feel is a good representation of the underlying performance within our underwriting business and it's something that we would expect to achieve in a normal year. I appreciate there haven't been many normal years of late. But there are other parts to our business, obviously, the broking part of our business, the premium funding part of our business isn't exposed to the underwriting volatility and we're getting good growth in that side of our business.
Okay. Thanks.
And your next question comes from the line of Craig Woolford of Citi, Sydney. Please ask your question.

Hi, guys. A question on the Resources segment with regards to the underlying cost growth, and if I back out that $55 million to get 6% mining cost growth, is that – firstly, is that right? And is that a good understanding of the underlying run rate of sort of natural cost pressures that the business is facing?

Well, having a look at, Craig, slide 33 in the supplementary pack, that gives you a pretty good indication of what costs have done to the first half of the year versus second half, and we'll be able to reduce down the costs. Just sort of talking more in terms of quantum, the costs for the second half in terms of total dollars compared to the first half are actually lower than the first half. And that's despite having higher production in the second half, an additional 1.2 million tonnes of production at Curragh. So, as we have commissioned a new plant at Curragh over the sort of last four or five months, we've been able to significantly increase our production, and that's been driving our cost structure down. And we've started the first month of this year with similar sort of costs that we've had in the second half of the year. So, we're seeing significant uplift as a result of increasing our production and commissioning new plant.
So, you're getting – just to understand that. So, you're able to offset the natural wage inflation and other cost pressures through productivity on this extra volume?
No. What I'm saying is in the first half of the year the costs were abnormally high.
Yeah.
And we've indicated about AUD55 million --
Yeah.

...associated with that. With the commissioning of the new plant, we've been able to drive our cost structure down. And we think the cost structure now is about where it should be. And we're driving to drop that even further as we move forward. If you're looking at then how do we sit compared to other export coal miners, we see that our cost structure is in the bottom quartile, so we're pretty competitive against other hard coking coal producers.

But as you said, the underlying cost, we continue to see pressures in the underlying cost structures. On a positive note, though, because of the downturn in the export metallurgical market, we are seeing a contractor availability increase as some mines adjust their production rates and reduce contractors. And another very good leading indicator of potentially where we're heading is haul-truck delivery times. So, if you purchase a haul-truck through, say, Caterpillar, the haul-truck delivery times have dropped down from about three years, six months ago, to about 33 weeks at the moment. So, it's a significantly reduced time to get a truck into the marketplace. So, I think they're all good leading indicators that hopefully some of the cost pressures we've had over the last two or three years maybe coming off a touch.
Okay. That's great. Thanks.
Sure.
Your next question comes from the line of David Cooke of Nomura, Sydney. Please ask your question.

Hi. This one is also for Stewart. Just having a look at that slide 33 on your mine costs – excuse me, I presume that does not include any of the royalty amounts on there. But I look at it and say that it has really flattened out during the second six months, and that includes the June quarter where you had significant uplift in production. So, I suppose, I'm trying to get a handle and get an understanding as to where you're going to be able to reduce that further outside of your contractor? And I supposed, therefore, that begs the question, what contractor cost now is a portion of your mine cash cost? Is it the material or is it still very small?

No, no. The contractor costs are very significant proportion of our cost. A lot of our overburden removal is done by contractors as opposed to – we basically do dragline operations with our own employees, but truck and shovel is done by contractors. So, there is, obviously, significant cost associated with contractor costs. Just looking at slide 33 that you made some comments about the costs have been fairly flat during the second half, as you see, the volume has kicked up and costs have come down a little bit over that period and we'll continue to work that down and July is slightly less than what June was.
And the outlook, you said you'd expect that to be able to come down over the six to 12 months.

Well, it depends on what the prevailing cost pressures are, whether they're heading upwards or downwards, and we've been operating on, clearly, an upward movement in terms of cost structure over the last three or so years. Some leading indicators are indicating that maybe it will come off a touch, but we've yet to see that in reality.
Okay. And final one, Stewart, when you talk about cost per tonne, is that cost per tonne including overburden removal, et cetera, or is that cost per the tonne of actual production of coal?
No, that's all our costs, mine site costs.
Okay. Thanks.
And there are no further questions at this time.
Thank you all very much. Have a good day. Happy to take any further questions through Mark Scatena and Alex (121:46). Thanks.
That concludes our conference for today. Thank you for participating. You may all now disconnect.
